conversations.content: Back again today? You're oddly persistent.
Pray, do not bristle so at the thought of company, for I come with a question.
I ask you, Midgardsormr: Can dragon and human forge a true bond together?
Impossible. Dragons do not meddle in the affairs of mortals.
It has always been so. Humans to their world and we to ours, and let each keep their own good company.
And if someone should arise to shatter that old order?
A hollow fantasy. Such a feat is beyond the reach of any.
Untested and impossible are two different beasts, and the wise do not make habit of declaring what shall never come to pass.
Know you this: At times, humans are a race capable of acts beyond the ken of even dragonkind.
...That dream again.
＂The wise do not make habit of declaring what shall never come to pass,＂ was it? Sage words indeed.
Yet how are we to glimpse possibility in the impossible? The laws of our world are so precisely BECAUSE they are immutable.
The humanoid races bend the knee to us, and we grant our favor in return. The notion we might stand as equals is—
Midgardsormr!
Ah, look. Another fool given to spouting hollow fantasies.
I have something to tell you!
If the words you mean to utter are, ＂Come now, let us live together,＂ I am quite weary of hearing them.
*sigh* (I had thought Alberius odd enough when he first met my storm unflinching.)
(Had I known he would then come to my abode day after day spouting nonsense, I'd have called forth a stronger gale.)
No, I'm here for something different today, Midgardsormr: I seek to pluck the fruits of your knowledge!
All the more reason for a muzzle. I've no cause to share knowledge with you.
Please! I've no one else to turn to on this besides a dragon such as yourself.
None of us humans have the faintest idea why the very fabric of space has rent, nor what to make of the rift it caused.
Very well. Speak.
...So then. You claim a number of villagers have gone missing, and that rifts in space have now begun to appear?
Correct, though I've only seen it once. Despite how mad it sounds, it was just as I described: a wound rent from nothing.
Naturally, I was curious, but it vanished as soon as I approached, leaving only a curious dark fog behind.
Black mana: Fell poison to the living. You would do well to keep your distance when encountering it in the future.
Good thing I resisted the urge to touch it!
Curiosity is lethal in large doses, human. ...Was aught else out of the ordinary?
Aside from the gaping holes in space? Hmm... Well, there do seem to be more fiends about than usual.
Hmm. As I suspected.
Then you know what's happening?!
In normal times, fiends would not easily take root in these lands, for my winds keep their kind at bay.
But as you say, their numbers swell of late.
Driven to rampage by black mana.
That same gloomy mist I saw?
Indeed. I did not know the mana's origin, but if you speak it true, something is amiss near your village.
This merits investigation.
Midgardsormr! Your form!
A matter of convenience when surveying a human settlement. Nothing more.
I had no idea you could DO that!
It is a rare skill among dragonkind, though not entirely unique.
The world truly is full of wonders...
Still, I'm surprised you'd go to such lengths to look into the matter on my account.
It has naught to do with you; I cannot sit idle after learning rifts are being torn in the very fabric of space.
This is a sign of another world exerting an influence on our own.
Are you suggesting there are entire worlds out there besides ours?
I suggest nothing. Instead, I state fact.
Astounding. The world is even wider than I thought! Say...can one pass through such a rift and emerge in another world?
You're swift to forget the lethal black mana seeping from it.
The space between worlds awaits beyond the rift—a cauldron of black mana infested with fiends. You would perish before you had time to appreciate the surroundings.
Oh... A shame there's not some kind of door that permits one to pass through while bypassing the space between.
Heed me well: Other worlds follow natural orders entirely unlike ours.
And yes, I heard tell of just such a door opening some seven centuries back...
But our world nearly fell to ruin at the hands of the Other as a result.
Good heavens!
Thus is the scale of danger entailed in the meeting of different worlds.
Those mistakes must not be repeated. If another world is attempting contact, such efforts must be stopped.
That task is mine in part, for dragonkind exists as protectors of the natural order.
(If this omen is dire enough to spur a dragon to act, what dark clouds loom on our world's horizon...?)
Welcome to my home, Midgardsormr.
Mmm. Charming.
Wait a moment and I'll introduce you.
Alberius, is that...?
Ah, perfect. Everyone, this is—
Those horns... That tail... It's a dragon!
Such a divine and glorious form!
Great dragon, have you come to aid us with the fiends and find our fellows who have gone missing?!
Praise be! Please, sir, right this way! We'll ready every hospitality our humble village can muster, so we will!
Um...
Your introduction appears unnecessary.
This is the forest where your people have seen rifts appear?
Disappearances, fiends, and rifts in space all occurring at once. Coincidence, or...?
There's got to be a connection.
Before considering that, another query: Why are you here?
I thought to help you investigate.
An offer both unneeded and unwanted. You are underfoot. Go home.
Yet I know these woods well and can be of use.
Human, I have known these woods for ages before you were even a twinkle in your mother's eye.
Ah. Of course. ...Still, if fiends appear, I will have your back! I've some skill in battle, if I may be a touch immodest.
And what would you do that a storm of howling winds could not?
Fair point. But...there must be something I can do.
There is not. Humans are capable of little, and I certainly do not require whatever small thing they might accomplish.
Dragons are possessed of power beyond your ken, so there is no need for us to work with you. Such has been the way of this world since time immemorial.
I disagree. Surely there must be some things which only humans can do.
So says the man who has managed to do nothing at all.  ...Hmm? Hold a moment. I am sensing a presence.
Hey, wait! We're not done talking here!
So this is the rift in question. But the distortion of the mana...
I'd feared the rifts were a sign of another world reaching out to encroach upon our own, but this is the reverse.
This rift was made by humans as part of a summoning. And given their recent rise, I wager the conjurer was attempting to call forth fiends.
But to what end...?
Oh, that's easy. Power.
I don't know which is more tiresome: your sad, relentless pursuit of me, or your insipid answer to that question
If power was the ultimate goal, there are far simpler paths to it. No living thing would deny its own survival instinct for such a purpose.
And humans are unique for fostering greed that outstrips even those instincts. They must've felt the returns justified the risk.
Idiocy.
Unlike most animals, humans know just how weak we are—which only serves to feed our hunger for strength.
I'm human. I understand the way we think better than you.
Which means this investigation will go faster if we work together. What say you?
AAAAAAAAUGH!
Who was that?!
This way!
Help! Please, somebody!
Sir, please help me! There are fiends after me!
Seize him, men—but stay your blades. I want this one alive.
Yes, sir!
What?!
Wait, and now the fiends are here?! This day just keeps getting worse!
HAAAAH!
A...dragon?! Graaagh!
You all right?!
Alberius! Er, yes, I'm fine, thanks to this right honorable dragon here!
Go with Alberius, human. I have business with this one.
Speak, human. Why are you summoning fiends from that other world, and what business do you have taking prisoners?
I...I was only... Urk! AAAAAAAUGH!
He's clutching at his throat!
*GASP* Huh...? Where...? Who am I? Why am I in the woods?
Amnesia? Ha! The most hackneyed ploy in all the books! We'll not fall for such—
Show me your neck.
Um...all right?
Is that a symbol of some kind?
It is a sigil—a curse, to be more precise. Its magic has stolen this man's memory.
Whoever placed it there isn't eager to have their minions spill secrets.
Damn!
The perpetrator is clearly a cautious sort. Sadly, I fear this to be a sign of the scale and nature of their ultimate plans.
We may not have caught the mastermind, but I am glad you are well regardless.
Not half as glad as me, Alberius. And thank you again, lord dragon.
Hmm? Why are all of you here?
You foul, lying dragon! You snake! Why did you forsake us?!
What?!
Why do you name Midgardsormr a liar?
Because we just lost another villager! He's supposed to be here to help us, but he can't even keep us safe!
Yet he saved THIS man's life not moments ago!
Then where is my husband, huh?! Why hasn't he come home?!
My daughter just vanished, too! Aren't the great dragons supposed to be man's protectors?!
Now, hold on a minute. I know you're upset, but you're being unreasonable!
Pay them no mind, Midgardsormr. They don't really...
Back again, are we?
You seem even more irascible than usual. Disgusted by the selfishness of man?
It's long since ceased to surprise me. They are a weak race, and so it is that our kind shall never join hands with theirs as peers.
Although—
No. There is no room for exception. The order of the world is bedrock.
＂The laws of our world are so precisely because they are immutable,＂ wasn't it? A sensible point then and now.
Yet no law exists which might shackle the future, and time ever carries change in its wake.
But surely you're aware, Midgardsormr...
The reason for these dreams.
Nnnh?!
The reason for these dreams...
(Now that I think on it, my dreams began soon after I first met Alberius.)
Midgardsormr!
You're not a quick learner, are you? Why have you come here when I've no business with you?
I am sorry.
And for what do you apologize?
For what the other villagers said to you. It was unfair, and I'm sorry for it.
Even if there were losses elsewhere, you still saved a man's life!
That man's survival was a coincidence. Nothing more.
I was investigating the rift, not working on your race's behalf.
Even so, we were the beneficiaries. And to turn about and repay you as we did is inexcusable.
You needn't shoulder the blame; human selfishness is another bedrock of the natural order.
The natural order?
Indeed. That which endures changeless over the eons becomes immutable law that none may sunder.
Humans have ever been weak creatures. They lack the strength to survive alone, and so look to those above them for aid.
If expectations of salvation are betrayed, they harbor resentment. Such is the human condition, as it has ever been.
That's...not true...
Does it truly ring so false in your ears?
...No. No, I suppose it doesn't.
We pray for rain so our crops might grow. But if too much rain ever ruins them, we turn about and curse the clouds.
Such emotions are a universal feature of the human heart. They merit neither remorse nor shame—they simply are.
This world is replete with unchanging things of that sort.
Immobile as mountains, ubiquitous as the air we breathe. They are laws of nature.
Is that why you claim humans and dragons will never live together?
You think that to be another part of the world's order?
If you've finally grasped that, you may cease your customary nonsense and simply accept the fact.
But is it truly so unshakable?
And even if so, is ＂unchanging＂ not just another word for ＂stagnant＂? A world of no progress and no growth is not one I want to aspire to.
Perhaps some of your bedrock laws are overdue for a change—and perhaps it's up to us to change them.
Fundamental laws? In need of change?
Just watch. I'll dig up your so-called bedrock and sculpt it into something new—something better.
A laughable boast. What can you, a mere human, hope to accomplish?
Plenty! But I'll start with changing that silly bit about mankind and dragons never working together as one.
Hmph. How very amusing. Well then, go on. Tell me your plan...
(The wind howls. Is it the harbinger of a coming storm, or...?)
(It is a bold claim to say you will unearth the bedrock of this world and sculpt it as you see fit, Alberius.)
That afternoon...
Just how is it you mean to alter the very foundations of our world, human?
By the two of us working together to solve this mystery.
And you propose to be of use in this endeavor...how, exactly?
I will allow myself to be captured and taken prisoner, and you will follow to see where I am taken.
I knew better than to expect much. Your plan is nothing more than begging help from a higher power, same as ever.
I haven't finished explaining. Hear me out. There's a reason to it.
Did it not strike you as odd that soldiers are here in the first place?
There are no outposts nearby. No bases. We've never seen one out this far, yet suddenly here they are. Why is that?
Mostlike it is a trap to ensnare prisoners.
They release the otherworldly fiends they'd summoned in order to terrorize the village.
And when its denizens turn to them for help, they swoop up the lot of them as minnows swimming into the fisher's net.
I thought the same.
We know they're after live captives, so we can use that to our advantage. Getting caught on purpose is the fastest way to learn who is behind all of this.
Whoever it is, they're cagey enough to seal the lips of their men, so we'll likely learn more inside than out.
I admit, it makes a certain sense—yet I fail to see how this plan holds anything but danger for you.
You've no guarantees they won't execute you on the spot once they have you.
Then why bother taking people alive at all? If they didn't have good reason not to kill, they wouldn't go through the hassle.
You've also no guarantee that I will come running to your rescue.
On that front, I have no doubt.
Oh?
Those soldiers were using fiends frenzied by black mana.
The longer this goes on, the greater their numbers will swell.
And fiends dripping with black mana overrunning the land isn't good for this world, right?
Just so. But that still presents no reason for me to aid you when I might just subdue the soldiers by force instead.
Only if you wish to replay past events. A dead man cannot tell what he knows, and the living have their memories wiped.
But if I learn the truth from the source and make it out alive, it is no longer an issue.
What do you say? Does my plan hold at least some merit?
You're quite the talker, aren't you?
(If I ever imagined something would drive me to beg a human's aid, it wasn't this.)
(Yet I can't deny his proposal is my— no, is OUR most efficient option.)
(Speaking of efficiency, why would the perpetrator summon otherworldly fiends?)
(If they wished to use fiends, this world has no shortage of its own.)
(And whence the need to abduct humans?)
Oh... A shame there's not some kind of door that permits one to pass through while bypassing the space between.
(Can that be their true aim?!)
This the next sacrifice, is it? Toss 'em up on the altar.
What are you planning to do with me?!
Tremble with joy, peasant, for you'll soon become the cornerstone of a great work that will bind the world together as one!
Binding the world as one? That's amazing! Right, then. Sacrifice away.
You're...more understanding about this than our usual sacrifices.
What can I say? I've gotten bored of the monotony of village life, and it would be an honor to be a part of something so grand!
But before you do it, I'm dying to know just what my life is being used for. ...Heh. Dying to know. That's good.
What use is knowing when death awaits?
Is it not natural for one selling his life to be curious what it is buying?
Surely this ＂great work＂ isn't just rounding up people and offing them—unless your army is no more than common brigands.
Silence, fool! Still, I refuse to allow such a laughable accusation to stand. If you are so curious of your life's use, I'll tell you...
We seek to open a gate to another world. Doing so, however, requires tremendous amounts of energy.
You sacrifices serve the noble purpose of supplying our vast store of mana.
A gate to another world?! Oh my, this IS a great work! Er, but what happens once you finally have it open?
As you will not be there to witness its opening, there is no need for you to know.
Then I shall tell him. These men look to resurrect the Other, who has been sealed away in the heart of the other world.
Who goes there?! And how do you— Aaaaaugh!
To style such fatal idiocy a ＂great work＂ is the very height of delusion.
Midgardsormr!
I did not wish to hear my suspicions confirmed, but you did well to loosen their tongues.
How did a dragon find this place?!
By following your delighted sacrifice there.
But...why is a dragon helping a human?
Captain! We must abandon this place!
None who know of our plans may live!
Plus, we're too close to stop now! We've succeeded in opening rifts to the space between worlds. All that remains now is to open the gate!
So the previous rifts have been failed attempts at this gate.
I do not fear you, dragon—and in fact, your mana should suffice to open the gate and see Lord Morsayati reborn!
I fear we cannot allow that.
The world shall not be permitted to fall into chaos once more! Haaaah!
Your altar lies shattered, and I have placed this land's mana back under my control. Your doomed plot is undone. It is over.
*cough* Heh heh... Over...? No... This is only the beginning...
My empire's preparations are...nearly complete. Stopping us...means nothing.
So IS it over?
For now.
(So they truly seek to awaken the Other.)
(Is that dark history set to repeat itself?)
Back again? You truly never grow weary of this, do you?
I wanted to thank you for saving my life.
That, and... It gladdens me that you agreed to team up.
Our interests aligned. That is all.
But you're glad you did it, yes?
I...suppose I will acknowledge that.
Do you still not think there's a way for humans and dragons to live together?
It is true there was meaning in joining hands with you in this isolated endeavor...
But the last days' events have also served to show the boundless foolishness of man.
Those soldiers slew their own in an effort to summon calamity upon the very world that gave them life and sustained them.
How is one to share a vision of the world with a race so benighted?
I can't deny this has been a showcase of humanity's worst traits, and I blame no one for thinking us fools.
But humanity's greatest strength is our ability to change, and I'm not ready to give up on our possibilities just yet.
You speak of possibilities, but...
Untested and impossible are two different beasts, and the wise do not make habit of declaring what shall never come to pass.
You are a human, so I would hear how YOU propose to change.
First, I will cease coming here.
I will undertake a journey and travel the world on my own two feet.
A journey, is it?
I first came here because I wanted to see a wider world than the one I knew.
But I've realized there is much you cannot see by simply gazing down from on high.
I want to meet all manner of souls— human, dragon, and otherwise—who think differently than I and learn from them.
Also, I'm worried about this empire the soldier mentioned, so I wish to know more of what's happening in the world.
That is quite the transformation.
Would you care to join me?
Hmm?
What better place to test whether or not humans and dragons can live together than on the open road?
I see you've no intention of changing your propensity for mad delusion.
Oh, but I'm serious. If the world's as wide as they say, maybe we'll find something that turns your natural order on its head.
You speak in vague possibilities.
Maybe, but that possibility is what I choose to believe in.
(Thinking back, this human has ever believed in what the future might hold.)
(The laws of the world are bedrock—yet to hold them as such is to reject change.)
(A world unchanging means history is condemned to repeat—and perhaps that is the ultimate consequence of an unchallenged order.)
(If that order could be changed, would the world and the future change with it?)
Just how is it you mean to alter the very foundations of our world, human?
By the two of us working together to solve this mystery.
I fear we cannot allow that.
The world shall not be permitted to fall into chaos once more! Haaaah!
And if someone should arise to shatter that old order?
(If protecting the world order means repeating the mistakes of the past...)
(Then will shattering that order and giving rise to a new one bring a different future? A better future, one that evades disaster...)
Hmm? Why'd you suddenly change form?
A matter of convenience when traveling the roads with a human.
Then you mean...?
I accept your invitation.
You have my thanks; I will feel much better out there with you at my side!
Be warned: I join not to aid, but to judge. I would see if you are truly fit to reshape the world's laws.
You swore to dig up my bedrock and sculpt it into something better, did you not?
I did, and I will. It's good to have you along for the journey, Midgardsormr.
(Perhaps you truly are the one to punch a hole in this long-stagnant order.)
Three centuries later...
It has been some time.
Indeed it has. You have changed much since departing on that journey.
Is that why you haven't shown up in my dreams since that day?
Heh. You would ask a question despite already knowing its answer?
Then I will provide the answer as well as the question: These dreams are my own doubt given form—doubt sown by Alberius.
Doubt from being bound by the old order, yet glimpsing the possibility of a bond between dragon and human.
Then I ask you once more, Midgardsormr: Can dragon and man forge a true bond?
They can. The days I lived with Alberius in centuries past are proof of this— and those bonds continue through time.
I shall protect this world he created, where dragon and man can journey as one.
Then it seems the promise is kept.
The promise?
A personal matter. I suspect we will not have the chance to speak again.
Then let me ask, if this be our final meeting: Who ARE you?
I am—
O great dragon of the forest! If you can hear my voice, then heed my call. Grant me the pactstone's power!
That voice...
It seems the time to awaken is come. Go, then. A new pact awaits you.
I leave the world to come in your care.
(I do not need to be asked to do my duty.)
(I carry with me the will of Alberius, and I shall see it done.)
I hear your voice, pact-seeker...
Now prove your feeble flesh can withstand the supreme power of a dragon!
And so the story finds its next hero...
